content.feeling: It feels like there's only one beat to the jump instead of two. There should be two because there is an axis change in the air. If I only feel one, I probably didn't change axis.
content.issue: Not changing axis in the air.
content.solution: Address the root causes: Lower body - Set: Squeeze free glute medius and engage skating inner thigh to align free leg's foot, knee, and hip. Step: Step perpendicular to skating edge, not parallel. Load: Switch hips - lift free side instead of loading with flat hips. Upper body - Set: Belly button should track knee and foot, not be behind the path of free side, to enable hinging onto standing hip.
content.regressions: Watch for: sassy hip, square hips, turning on ice before jumping, free leg and arm kicking across body, stepping down with misalignment.

content.feeling: Hip is sassy (sticking out to the side) during the load phase
content.issue: Free glute medius and skating inner thigh not squeezing in the set.
content.solution: On the set, squeeze free glute medius and engage skating inner thigh together. Prime the glute medius to fire. This aligns the free leg's foot, knee, and hip so they're not primed to sassy when stepping down.

content.feeling: Hips are square (not rotated/switched) during the load
content.issue: Not switching hips, loading with flat hips instead of lifting free side.
content.solution: Switch hips - lift the free side. Free and standing hips need to switch. After loading and lifting the free hip, then start hinging into the standing hip.

content.feeling: Rotation happens on the ice before leaving the ice
content.issue: Pre-rotation - turning on the ice instead of in the air.
content.solution: Jump straight up, not turning. Set up jumps with marking posts to ensure straight entry.

content.feeling: Free leg and arm move across the body rather than extending outward
content.issue: Free side not staying back, causing compensatory movement across the body.
content.solution: Keep free side back. Free leg and arm should extend out, not across the body.

content.feeling: When stepping down, need to make multiple adjustments - hips, chest, and dropping
content.issue: Hip isn't engaging and belly button not tracking knee and foot in the set.
content.solution: On the set, ensure belly button tracks the knee and foot. Engage the hip properly. Prime glute medius to fire.

content.feeling: Step direction feels parallel to the edge rather than perpendicular
content.issue: Stepping parallel causes hips to open up excessively.
content.solution: Step perpendicular to your skating edge, not parallel

bodyParts.description: Should be squeezing along with standing inner thigh to align free leg's foot, knee, and hip
Should be engaging/squeezing along with free glute medius to maintain alignment
Foot, knee, and hip should be aligned. If not squeezing glute medius and inner thigh, they become unaligned and primed to sassy when stepping down
Should track the knee and foot, not be behind the path of free side. This enables hinging onto standing hip
Should lift. Free and standing hips need to switch - lift free side instead of loading with flat hips
Should switch with free hip. After loading and lifting the free hip, then start hinging into the standing hip
Should be squeezing together with standing glute in the set and through the load
Should be squeezing together with free glute in the set and through the load
Right side load: starts squeezing while skating lat holds shape. Left side load: is squeezing while skating lat holds shape
Right side load: holds shape while free lat starts squeezing. Left side load: holds shape while free lat is squeezing
Switch between being 'engaged/squeezing' and static/holding from entrance to load. Cross tension (seatbelt): both are holding shape
Should change in the air - there should be two beats to the jump, not one. If only feeling one beat, axis didn't change.

content.content: Set up jumps with marking posts to ensure straight entry.
Squeeze free glute medius and engage skating inner thigh in the set to align free leg's foot, knee, and hip.
Belly button should track the knee and foot in the set, not be behind the path of free side.
Hold the load and feel the free side staying back. Get a sense for when it starts to release so you can use that timing to jump.
Switch hips at the load - lift the free side instead of loading with flat hips. After loading and lifting the free hip, then start hinging into the standing hip.

The lats switch between being engaged/squeezing and static/holding from entrance to load. Right side load: free lat starts squeezing while skating lat holds shape. Cross tension (seatbelt): both hold shape. Left side load: free lat is squeezing while skating lat holds shape.
Free and standing glutes should be squeezing together in the set and through the load.
Do a baby waltz jump, but jump straight up without turning.
